author: sky.cactus
content: I think if we have the manpower to build out a cross-platform test suite that covers the edge cases that would be ideal.  However, writing the edge-case files like has been done I think is significantly lower engineering effort, and so may be a more pragmatic solution.

author: sky.cactus
content: In general, anything related to specifications that can be automated is good because it is less likely to fall out of date and it is easier for clients to verify compatibility.  But good is often expensive.

author: ppf.
content: i have this assumption that querying for ethereum-state that is distributed through a big amount of smartcontracts will be slower than querying state which is only in 1 smartcontract because of the distance between each state in the merkletree. does this make sense?

author: ppf.
content: asking because right now I try to query all rocketpool state naively by just querying state through getter-functions in the smartcontracts, its slow. will now try to instead subscribe for emitted events and only query updated state.

author: sky.cactus
content: While one can imagine an optimization where you cache recently accessed state, and having a particular account be warm can avoid a disk hit, I don't think you should assume that you are getting cache hits.

author: sky.cactus
content: This is definitely a better strategy in most cases, and one of the primary reasons why events exist I believe.

author: ppf.
content: thanks, yeah i thought so - querying state from 500 different smartcontracts takes a lot more time than querying the same number of state from just one smartcontract. was wondering about my assumption that location of state in memory is the cause.

author: ppf.
content: filtering events results in much less queries anyway

author: sky.cactus
content: Are you doing the query via a single getter in the faster case, or are you making 500 JSON-RPC calls in both cases?

author: ppf.
content: multiple rpc-calls in both cases

author: sky.cactus
content: That surprises me a bit, but not terribly.
